comment.author: 63098246@N00
comment._content: is this a real picture?... to me the boat and the people on it look somehow hand made...

comment.author: 20527707@N00
comment._content: Yes its real.  You have to remember that the Carpathia was In very frigid waters.  The captain of  of the Carpathia didn't have any heating systems on because the steam was needed to get to the Titanic. You are looking at a condensation blur. The film was glass. Then there is the breath of the person taking to picture. You can see the breath on the top of the picture. Looks like fog.

comment.author: 23369652@N08
comment._content: If you enlarge it, it actually looks like someone sketched in features on some of the faces and outlined other parts.  It also looks like their is  a fingerprint on the image, center, bottom

comment.author: 45359107@N00
comment._content: Looks like someone retouch the picture using a pen or something over vanished parts drawing the shadows.

comment.realname: lifeasdaddy ...a guy, his wife, and their son...
comment.author: 13267298@N00
comment._content: Looks retouched to me too.  No big deal.  It porbably had to be printed in a newspaper or magazine with a photo printing process without today's definition - so they needed to outline the important parts.

comment.author: 23072476@N02
comment._content: retouching like that on photography was common back then.  I see it a lot.

comment.author: 29079609@N02
comment._content:
this is probably boat #6, launched 3rd overall, 1st on Port side @12:55 AM.,
from FIRST CLASS Deck, Port
It is the best match as this photo fits the description of that boat's survivors:
25, only FIRST CLASS and CREW
the only male passenger allowed on volunteered to serve as a sailor.

this photo has 25 identifiable people, only 3 men, many women appear very well dressed.  being launched early accounts for the lack of men, and people overall.

comment.author: 9358078@N06
comment._content: It looks as there was a boat,(3hours later!) comming to help save people,that perished later,and wiser !!Praise lord!

comment.author: 61361160@N00
comment._content: This photograph is part of the Indicommons.org post April 15, 1912: The Titanic.

comment.author: 50454528@N00
comment._content: Hi, I'm an admin for a group called PERSONAL BEST - Preserving Meaningful Moments, and we'd love to have this added to the group!

comment.author: 26724339@N00
comment._content: So (amongst others) this boat contained quartermaster Robert Hichens, the man at the wheel of the Titanic at the moment of impact, crewman Frederick Fleet, who first sighted the iceberg, the "unsinkable" Molly Brown, and newly pregnant Mary Eloise Smith, who lost her newly-wed husband - they were returning from their honeymoon.

comment.author: 56466542@N02
comment._content: it looks sketched at the bottom right corner....

comment.author: 63860770@N07
comment._content: You are probably correct Stella Stine, it was fairly common for news services like Bain to edit photos to sharpen lines that weren't clear or on occasion white out parts of the shot.
